keywordspec.name: DataTypesLibrary
keywordspec.doc:
This Library has Data Types.
It has some in ``__init__`` and others in the `Keywords`.
The DataTypes are the following that should be linked. `HttpCredentials` , `GeoLocation` , `Small` and `AssertionOperator`.

init.name: __init__
init.doc:
This is the init Docs.
It links to `Set Location` keyword and to `GeoLocation` data type.

kw.name: Assert Something

arguments.repr: value, operator: AssertionOperator | None = None, exp: str = something?

kw.doc:
This links to `AssertionOperator` .
This is the next Line that links to `Set Location` .

arguments.repr: arg: CustomType, arg2: CustomType2, arg3: CustomType, arg4: Unknown
funny: bool | int | float | str | AssertionOperator | Small | GeoLocation | None = equal

arg.repr: funny: bool | int | float | str | AssertionOperator | Small | GeoLocation | None = equal
arg.name: funny

arguments.repr: list_of_str: List[str], dict_str_int: Dict[str, int], whatever: Any, *args: List[Any]
arg: Literal[1, 'xxx', b'yyy', True, None, one]

arg.repr: arg: Literal[1, 'xxx', b'yyy', True, None, one]
arg.name: arg

type.name: Any
type.doc: Any value is accepted. No conversion is done.

type.name: AssertionOperator
type.doc:
This is some Doc
This has was defined by assigning to __doc__.

type.name: boolean
type.doc:
Strings ``TRUE``, ``YES``, ``ON`` and ``1`` are converted to Boolean ``True``, the empty string as well as strings ``FALSE``, ``NO``, ``OFF`` and ``0`` are converted to Boolean ``False``, and the string ``NONE`` is converted to the Python ``None`` object. Other strings and other accepted values are passed as-is, allowing keywords to handle them specially if needed. All string comparisons are case-insensitive.
Examples: ``TRUE`` (converted to ``True``), ``off`` (converted to ``False``), ``example`` (used as-is)

type.name: CustomType
type.doc: Converter method doc is used when defined.

type.name: CustomType2
type.doc: Class doc is used when converter method has no doc.

type.name: dictionary
type.doc:
Strings must be Python [https://docs.python.org/library/stdtypes.html#dict|dictionary] literals. They are converted to actual dictionaries using the [https://docs.python.org/library/ast.html#ast.literal_eval|ast.literal_eval] function. They can contain any values ``ast.literal_eval`` supports, including dictionaries and other containers.
If the type has nested types like ``dict[str, int]``, items are converted to those types automatically. This in new in Robot Framework 6.0.
Examples: ``{'a': 1, 'b': 2}``, ``{'key': 1, 'nested': {'key': 2}}``

type.name: float
type.doc:
Conversion is done using Python's [https://docs.python.org/library/functions.html#float|float] built-in function.
Starting from RF 4.1, spaces and underscores can be used as visual separators for digit grouping purposes.
Examples: ``3.14``, ``2.9979e8``, ``10 000.000 01``

type.name: GeoLocation
type.doc:
Defines the geolocation.
- ``latitude`` Latitude between -90 and 90. - ``longitude`` Longitude between -180 and 180. - ``accuracy`` *Optional* Non-negative accuracy value. Defaults to 0.
Example usage: ``{'latitude': 59.95, 'longitude': 30.31667}``

type.name: integer
type.doc:
Conversion is done using Python's [https://docs.python.org/library/functions.html#int|int] built-in function. Floating point numbers are accepted only if they can be represented as integers exactly. For example, ``1.0`` is accepted and ``1.1`` is not.
Starting from RF 4.1, it is possible to use hexadecimal, octal and binary numbers by prefixing values with ``0x``, ``0o`` and ``0b``, respectively.
Starting from RF 4.1, spaces and underscores can be used as visual separators for digit grouping purposes.
Examples: ``42``, ``-1``, ``0b1010``, ``10 000 000``, ``0xBAD_C0FFEE``

type.name: list
type.doc:
Strings must be Python [https://docs.python.org/library/stdtypes.html#list|list] literals. They are converted to actual lists using the [https://docs.python.org/library/ast.html#ast.literal_eval|ast.literal_eval] function. They can contain any values ``ast.literal_eval`` supports, including lists and other containers.
If the type has nested types like ``list[int]``, items are converted to those types automatically. This in new in Robot Framework 6.0.
Examples: ``['one', 'two']``, ``[('one', 1), ('two', 2)]``

type.name: Literal
type.doc:
Only specified values are accepted. Values can be strings, integers, bytes, Booleans, enums and None, and used arguments are converted using the value type specific conversion logic.
Strings are case, space, underscore and hyphen insensitive, but exact matches have precedence over normalized matches.

type.name: None
type.doc: String ``NONE`` (case-insensitive) is converted to Python ``None`` object. Other values cause an error.

type.name: Small
type.doc:
This is the Documentation.
This was defined within the class definition.

type.name: string
type.doc: All arguments are converted to Unicode strings.
